across.text: Asian deity placed river by a river in Asia
across.explanation: BRAHMAPUTRA(i.e. ‚Äúa river in Asia‚Äù. A big ‚Äòun too, by all accounts.) Solution is BRAHMA, the Hindu Creator god (i.e. ‚ÄúAsian deity‚Äù) followed by PUT (i.e. ‚Äúplaced‚Äù) then R (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúriver‚Äù) and finally A, like so: BRAHMA-PUT-R-A. Chalk one to my Bradford‚Äôs here, as there are several hundred thousand rivers out there I‚Äôve never heard of.

across.text: Battle line‚Äôs cut in retreat
across.explanation: FLIGHT(i.e. ‚Äúretreat‚Äù). Solution is FIGHT (i.e. ‚Äúbattle‚Äù) with L (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúline‚Äù) ‚Äúcut in‚Äù like so: F(L)IGHT.

across.text: With Bill following, say ‚ÄúI‚Äôm shocked!‚Äù
across.explanation: EGAD(i.e. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm shocked!‚Äù). Solution is AD (i.e. ‚Äúbill‚Äù, as in a shortened form of ‚Äúadvertisement‚Äù ‚Äì ignore the misleading capitalisation) which is placed behind or ‚Äúfollowing‚Äù EG (i.e. ‚Äúsay‚Äù, as in for example), like so: EG-AD. Yes, I immediately thought ofPinky and the Brainwhen I got this. I am a massive child. (Thumbs nose and sticks out tongue.)

across.text: Worry for each kind of wine knocked back
across.explanation: PERTURB(i.e. ‚Äúworry‚Äù). Solution is PER (i.e. ‚Äúfor each‚Äù) followed by BRUT (i.e. ‚Äúkind of wine‚Äù) reversed or ‚Äúknocked back‚Äù, like so: PER-TURB.

across.text: Set off, with a way to cross river
across.explanation: AROUSED(i.e. ‚Äúset off‚Äù, as in to trigger rather than to launch). Solution is A followed by RD (i.e. ‚Äúway‚Äù, as in a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúroad‚Äù) once it has been wrapped around or ‚Äúcrossing‚Äù OUSE (i.e. ‚Äúriver‚Äù), like so: A-R(OUSE)D.

across.text: Steward to go off, returning on time for resolution
across.explanation: JANITOR(i.e. ‚Äústeward‚Äù). Solution is ROT (i.e. ‚Äúto go off‚Äù) reversed (indicated by ‚Äúreturning‚Äù) and placed behind JAN I (i.e. ‚Äútime for resolution‚Äù, as in New Year‚Äôs Day), like so: JAN-I-TOR.

across.text: Secretly touring some countries in wild fashion
across.explanation: INCONTINENTLY(i.e. ‚Äúin wild fashion‚Äù ‚Äì I mean, it‚Äôs one way to describe it, I guess). Solution is INLY (i.e. ‚Äúsecretly‚Äù ‚Äì it‚Äôs one way to describe it, I guess) wrapped around or ‚Äútouring‚Äù CONTINENT (i.e. ‚Äúsome countries‚Äù), like so: IN(CONTINENT)LY.

across.text: Service dispatched, carrying ace stuff
across.explanation: SACRAMENT(i.e. ‚Äúservice‚Äù, as in a ceremony). Solution is SENT (i.e. ‚Äúdispatched‚Äù) wrapped around or ‚Äúcarrying‚Äù A (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúace‚Äù used on playing cards) and CRAM (i.e. ‚Äú[to] stuff‚Äù), like so: S(A-CRAM)ENT.

across.text: House staff do twirls
across.explanation: TUDOR(i.e. ‚Äúhouse‚Äù, as in the dynasty of kings and queens who ruled England, Ireland and Wales between 1485 and 1603). Solution is ROD (i.e. ‚Äústaff‚Äù) and UT (i.e. ‚Äúdo‚Äù, as in the musical note ‚Äúdo‚Äù or ‚Äúdoh‚Äù. Once upon a time this used to be ‚Äúut‚Äù, it says here), which are both reversed (indicated by ‚Äútwirls‚Äù), like so: TU-DOR. One of those clues where you get the solution fairly easily and then spend ages trying to figure out what on earth the setter was playing at.

across.text: In the main, it‚Äôs outstanding publicity with name on the right
across.explanation: PROMONTORY(i.e. ‚Äúin the main, it‚Äôs outstanding‚Äù ‚Äì setters love using ‚Äúmain‚Äù to mean the sea, and a promontory is a headland or cape that juts out into the sea).Not quite sure about this one, so watch out. I get that PR is ‚Äúpublicity‚Äù, being a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúpress release‚Äù, and ‚Äúon the right‚Äù gets you ON TORY (as in the right-leaning Conservative Party) but the OM bit leaves me cold. It‚Äôs a recognised abbreviation of Order of Merit, perhaps, but that‚Äôs more a title than a name. Maybe the setter is playing fast and loose here, which wouldn‚Äôt be an isolated case. Ah, sod it, I‚Äôm moving on.[EDIT: A big thank you to Tommy in the comments for clarifying this one. Publicity is PROMO, not PR as I had it. Then you have N (a recognised abbreviation for ‚Äúname‚Äù) and finally TORY (for ‚Äúthe right‚Äù). Argh! It looks so simple seeing it written down! üòÄ ‚Äì LP]

across.text: Jet circles area, quiet or loud?
across.explanation: FLASHY(i.e. ‚Äúloud‚Äù). Solution is FLY (i.e. ‚Äú[to] jet‚Äù) wrapped around or ‚Äúcircling‚Äù A (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúarea‚Äù) and SH (i.e. ‚Äúquiet‚Äù), like so: FL(A-SH)Y.

across.text: Without hesitation, making free drink
across.explanation: LIBATION(i.e. ‚Äúdrink‚Äù). Solution is LIBERATION (i.e. ‚Äúmaking free‚Äù) with the ER removed (indicated by ‚Äúwithout hesitation‚Äù).

across.text: Power to hurt a biologist, not European chemist
across.explanation: PHARMACOLOGIST(i.e. ‚Äúchemist‚Äù). Solution is P (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúpower‚Äù) followed by HARM (i.e. ‚Äúto hurt‚Äù) then A and then ECOLOGIST (i.e. ‚Äúbiologist‚Äù) once the initial E has been removed (indicated by ‚Äúnot European‚Äù, E being a recognised abbreviation of ‚ÄúEuropean‚Äù), like so: P-HARM-A-COLOGIST.

across.text: One‚Äôs very sharp at English exam, amazingly
across.explanation: MEATAXE(i.e. ‚Äúone‚Äôs very sharp‚Äù. One is also a hyphenated word in my dictionary, but there you go). Solution is an anagram (indicated by ‚Äúamazingly‚Äù) of AT EXAM and E (a recognised abbreviation of ‚ÄúEnglish‚Äù).

across.text: Hopeless sort of computer game is included in trial
across.explanation: PESSIMIST(i.e. ‚Äúhopeless sort‚Äù). Solution is SIM (i.e. ‚Äúsort of computer game‚Äù, e.g. a flight simulator) and IS placed or ‚Äúincluded in‚Äù PEST (i.e. ‚Äútrial‚Äù ‚Äì the setter has gone deep into the definitions here, but a trial can be a pest or nuisance), like so: PES(SIM-IS)T.

across.text: Possessing urge, laugh? This creature might
across.explanation: HYENA(i.e. ‚Äúthis creature might [laugh]‚Äù). Solution is YEN (i.e. ‚Äúurge‚Äù) which is placed in or ‚Äúpossessed‚Äù by HA (i.e. ‚Äúlaugh‚Äù), like so: H(YEN)A.

across.text: Filling of jam, plenty or enough?
across.explanation: AMPLE(i.e. ‚Äúenough‚Äù). ‚ÄúFilling of‚Äù indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: J(AM PLE)NTY.

across.text: Like certain characters in drug affair
across.explanation: UPPER CASE(i.e. ‚Äúlike certain characters‚Äù). Solution is UPPER (i.e. ‚Äúdrug‚Äù) followed by CASE (i.e. ‚Äúaffair‚Äù).

across.text: Recover or recovered like books?
across.explanation: REBOUND(i.e. ‚Äúrecover‚Äù). Solution also riffs on how books are bound in covers, so if they are re-covered, they are re-bound. Best clue of the puzzle. Very well played.

across.text: Caring too much to evict and reprove criminal
across.explanation: OVERPROTECTIVE(i.e. ‚Äúcaring too much‚Äù). ‚ÄúCriminal‚Äù indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TO EVICT and REPROVE.

across.text: Fashionably petite and fit one, that Parisian
across.explanation: BOUTIQUE(i.e. ‚Äúfashionably petite‚Äù). Solution is BOUT (i.e. ‚Äúfit‚Äù) followed by I (i.e. ‚Äú[Roman numeral] one‚Äù) and QUE (i.e. ‚Äúthat Parisian‚Äù, i.e. the French for ‚Äúthat‚Äù).

across.text: Feel anger for one half of match, we hear?
across.explanation: BRIDLE(i.e. ‚Äúfeel anger‚Äù). ‚ÄúWe hear‚Äù indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of BRIDAL (i.e. ‚Äúone half of match‚Äù or marriage).

across.text: Rock star isn‚Äôt in school
across.explanation: ST TRINIANS(i.e. fictitious boarding ‚Äúschool‚Äù created by Ronald Searle ‚Äì I used to love the old St Trinians movies back when I was even more of a massive child than I am today). ‚ÄúRock‚Äù indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of STAR ISNT IN.

across.text: Follow is about right for this
across.explanation: TRAIL. The clue riffs on how TAIL and TRAIL both satisfy ‚Äúfollow‚Äù, and how wrapping the former ‚Äúabout‚Äù R (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúright‚Äù) will get you the latter. You get the idea.

across.text: Government supporter in charge, in fact
across.explanation: STATISTIC(i.e. ‚Äúfact‚Äù). Solution is STATIST (i.e. ‚Äúgovernment supporter‚Äù) followed by IC (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúin charge‚Äù).

across.text: Stepping on court game‚Äôs dividing lines
across.explanation: DOUBLE SPACING(i.e. ‚Äú[gaps] dividing lines‚Äù). Solution is PACING (i.e. ‚Äústepping‚Äù) placed after or ‚Äúon‚Äù DOUBLES (i.e. ‚Äú[tennis] court game‚Äù).

across.text: Bow‚Äôs straight with recording for a dance
across.explanation: ONE-STEP(i.e. ‚Äúdance‚Äù). Solution is HONEST (i.e. ‚Äústraight‚Äù) with the initial H removed (indicated by ‚ÄúBow‚Äù, referring to how Cockneys drop their aitches ‚Äì Cockneys are those born within earshot of Bow Bells) and followed by EP (i.e. ‚Äúrecording‚Äù, specifically an Extended Play single), like so: ONEST-EP.

across.text: Youngster redeveloping the London borough
across.explanation: LAMBETH(i.e. ‚ÄúLondon borough‚Äù). Solution is LAMB (i.e. ‚Äúyoungster‚Äù) followed by an anagram (indicated by ‚Äúredeveloping‚Äù) of THE, like so: LAMB-ETH.

across.text: Desire this person has to be caustic
across.explanation: EROSIVE(i.e. ‚Äúto be caustic‚Äù). Solution is EROS (i.e. ‚Äúdesire [is] this person‚Äù) followed by I‚ÄôVE (i.e. ‚Äúhas‚Äù).

across.text: It‚Äôs formed by a group of signatories?
across.explanation: NATO(i.e. ‚Äúit‚Äôs formed by a group [of countries]‚Äù). ‚ÄúOf‚Äù indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, likes so: SIG(NATO)RIES.

across.text: Caught fabric in drawer
across.explanation: CRAYON(i.e. ‚Äúdrawer‚Äù, as in something used to draw stuff). Solution is C (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúcaught‚Äù used in ball games) followed by RAYON (i.e. ‚Äúfabric‚Äù).

across.text: Person seeking return in cattle pen
across.explanation: STOCKHOLDER. Solution satisfies ‚Äúperson seeking return [on investment]‚Äù and ‚Äúcattle pen‚Äù, as in a STOCK HOLDER.

down.text: Maybe John‚Äôs fitting in again, given time
down.explanation: BAPTIST(i.e. ‚Äúmaybe John‚Äù, as in John the Baptist). Solution is APT (i.e. ‚Äúfitting‚Äù) placed ‚Äúin‚Äù BIS (i.e. ‚Äúagain‚Äù ‚Äì in musical lingo this indicates a section is to be repeated) and then followed by T (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äútime‚Äù), like so: B(APT)IS-T.

down.text: Enchanting remark from a villain wearing a pair of undergarments
down.explanation: ABRACADABRA(i.e. ‚Äúenchanting remark‚Äù). Solution is CAD (i.e. ‚Äúvillain‚Äù) that is surrounded by or ‚Äúwearing‚Äù ‚Äúa pair of‚Äù A BRA (i.e. ‚Äúundergarment‚Äù), like so: A-BRA-(CAD)-A-BRA.

down.text: Think of the late or early period in speech
down.explanation: MOURN(i.e. ‚Äúthink of the late‚Äù ‚Äì late being a way of describing someone who is deceased). ‚ÄúIn speech‚Äù indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of MORN (i.e. ‚Äúearly period‚Äù).

down.text: Clip up court robes if high official there
down.explanation: PUBLIC PROSECUTOR(i.e. ‚Äú[court] official‚Äù). ‚ÄúIf high‚Äù indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of CLIP UP COURT ROBES.

down.text: Landed up penning composer‚Äôs moving account?
down.explanation: TRAVELOG(i.e. ‚Äúaccount‚Äù). Solution is GOT (i.e. ‚Äúlanded‚Äù) reversed (indicated by ‚Äúup‚Äù, this being a down clue) and placed around or ‚Äúpenning‚Äù Maurice RAVEL (i.e. ‚Äúcomposer‚Äù best known for his work,Bolero), like so: T(RAVEL)OG.

down.text: Addresses a set of lines in mail briefly
down.explanation: APOSTROPHES(i.e. ‚Äúaddresses‚Äù, or, as my Chambers has it, ‚Äúa sudden turning away from the ordinary course of a speech to address some person or object present or absent‚Äù. Not a definition that sprang to mind, but I like it.) Solution is A then STROPHE (i.e. ‚Äúa set of lines‚Äù ‚Äì off to my Chambers again: a strophe is ‚Äú(in a Greek play) the song sung by the chorus as it moved to one side, answered by an exact counterpart‚Äù. So there you go) once it has been placed ‚Äúin‚Äù POST (i.e. ‚Äúmail‚Äù) with its last letter removed (indicated by ‚Äúbriefly‚Äù) like so: A-PO(STROPHE)S. A clue that scans rather well once you take a step back from it.

down.text: Suspect roughly apprehended in case of felony
down.explanation: FISHY(i.e. ‚Äúsuspect‚Äù). Solution is ISH (i.e. ‚Äúroughly‚Äù) placed in or ‚Äúapprehended‚Äù by FY (i.e. ‚Äúcase of felony‚Äù, i.e. the first and last letters of ‚Äúfelony‚Äù), like so: F(ISH)Y.

down.text: Below River Test, one last character with lots of works?
down.explanation: INDUSTRIALIZED(i.e. ‚Äúwith lots of works‚Äù). Solution is INDUS (i.e. Asian ‚Äúriver‚Äù and another big‚Äô un) followed by TRIAL (i.e. ‚Äútest‚Äù ‚Äì ignore the misleading capitalisation) then I (i.e. ‚Äú[Roman numeral] one‚Äù) and ZED (i.e. ‚Äúlast character‚Äù), like so: INDUS-TRIAL-I-ZED. Clever, but as far as my patience was concerned, the river mini-theme had rather ran its course by this point, if you‚Äôll forgive the pun.

down.text: ‚ÄúHello, sailor‚Äù is appropriate
down.explanation: HIJACK(i.e. to steal or ‚Äúappropriate‚Äù). Solution is HI (i.e. ‚Äúhello‚Äù) and JACK (i.e. one of many words meaning ‚Äúsailor‚Äù). Another very neat clue. Well played.

down.text: Nearly go out and attack poor child
down.explanation: GUTTERSNIPE(i.e. ‚Äúpoor child‚Äù). Solution is GUTTER (i.e. ‚Äúnearly go out‚Äù) followed by SNIPE (i.e. ‚Äúattack‚Äù).

down.text: Mimic US writer, an unknown Kansan
down.explanation: DOROTHY(i.e. ‚ÄúKansan‚Äù, specifically the main character ofThe Wizard of Oz). Solution is DO (i.e. ‚Äú[to] mimic‚Äù) followed by Philip ROTH (i.e. ‚ÄúUS writer‚Äù ‚Äì an unwritten rule of the Times crossword is that people can only be used in clues or solutions so long as they are dead. This means setters have clues lined up for future use in much the same way as newspaper editors have pre-prepared obituaries. That‚Äôs nice, isn‚Äôt it?) and finally Y (i.e. ‚Äúunknown‚Äù ‚Äì setters love using this to represent X, Y or Z in their solutions), like so: DO-ROTH-Y.

down.text: Fashionable label brought back maybe crude design
down.explanation: INTAGLIO, which is a figure or ‚Äúdesign‚Äù cut into any substance. Solution is IN (i.e. ‚Äúfashionable‚Äù) followed by TAG (i.e. ‚Äúlabel‚Äù) and OIL (i.e. ‚Äúmaybe crude‚Äù) which is reversed (indicated by ‚Äúbrought back‚Äù), like so: IN-TAG-LIO. One I got from the wordplay, if I‚Äôm honest.

down.text: Artist to draw depressing image of existence
down.explanation: RAT RACE(i.e. ‚Äúdepressing image of existence‚Äù). Solution is RA (i.e. ‚Äúartist‚Äù, specifically a Royal Academician) followed by TRACE (i.e. ‚Äúto draw‚Äù).

down.text: I‚Äôm grateful to get recurrent pain in bones
down.explanation: TARSI(i.e. ‚Äúbones‚Äù, as in the plural of tarsus). Solution is TA (i.e. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm grateful‚Äù) followed by RSI (i.e. ‚Äúrecurrent pain‚Äù, specifically Repetitive Strain Injury).

down.text: Hospital worker puts up with wood that‚Äôs cut
down.explanation: PORTERHOUSE STEAK(i.e. ‚Äúcut [of meat]‚Äù). Solution is PORTER (i.e. ‚Äúhospital worker‚Äù) followed by HOUSES (i.e. ‚Äúputs up‚Äù) and TEAK (i.e. ‚Äúwood‚Äù). As repeats go, this is a doozie. Not only did the same solution appearback in puzzle 1375but it used the exact same wordplay in its construction (then the clue was ‚Äúworker at lodge stores wood and food‚Äù) and was placed in the exact same position of a grid that used the exact same layout. Quick! Somebody call theFortean Times! #Sarcasm

down.text: Smoker to get over source of discomfort
down.explanation: LUMBAGO(i.e. ‚Äúsource of discomfort‚Äù). Solution is LUM, a Scottish word for a chimney (i.e. ‚Äúsmoker‚Äù ‚Äì this word was fresh in my mind having also made an appearance in last week‚Äôs puzzle) followed by BAG (i.e. ‚Äúto get‚Äù) and O (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúover‚Äù used in cricket).

down.text: Time to move inelegantly in pants
down.explanation: TWADDLE(i.e. rubbish or ‚Äúpants‚Äù). Solution is T (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äútime‚Äù) followed by WADDLE (i.e. ‚Äúto move inelegantly‚Äù).

down.text: I collect PayPal transfers in fury
down.explanation: APOPLECTICALLY(i.e. ‚Äúin fury‚Äù). ‚ÄúTransfers‚Äù indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of I COLLECT PAYPAL.

down.text: Home cover‚Äôs included fairly
down.explanation: HABITAT(i.e. ‚Äúhome‚Äù). Solution is HAT (i.e. ‚Äúcover‚Äù) wrapped around or ‚Äúincluding‚Äù A BIT (i.e. ‚Äúfairly‚Äù), like so: H(A-BIT)AT.

down.text: The last word in divine pickle
down.explanation: PREDICAMENT(i.e. a sticky situation or ‚Äúpickle‚Äù). Solution is AMEN (i.e. ‚Äúthe last word‚Äù) placed ‚Äúin‚Äù PREDICT (i.e. ‚Äú[to] divine‚Äù), like so: PREDIC(AMEN)T.

down.text: Judge turned up on pitch
down.explanation: RATER(i.e. ‚Äújudge‚Äù). Solution is RE (i.e. ‚Äúon‚Äù or regarding something ‚Äì think email replies) and TAR (i.e. ‚Äúpitch‚Äù) both reversed or ‚Äúturned up‚Äù, this being a down clue, like so: RAT-ER.

down.text: Leader of air force about to release bold lady
down.explanation: ADVENTURESS(i.e. ‚Äúbold lady‚Äù). Solution is A (i.e. ‚Äúleader of air‚Äù, i.e. the first letter of ‚Äúair‚Äù) and DURESS (i.e. ‚Äúforce‚Äù) wrapped ‚Äúabout‚Äù VENT (i.e. ‚Äúto release‚Äù), like so: A-D(VENT)URESS.

down.text: Quail if nude modelling without right attributes
down.explanation: UNQUALIFIED(i.e. ‚Äúwithout right attributes‚Äù). ‚ÄúModelling‚Äù indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of QUAIL IF NUDE. A clue that scans rather well.

down.text: Moderate starter of p√¢t√© the only thing I consumed
down.explanation: PALLIATE(i.e. ‚Äúmoderate‚Äù). Solution is P (i.e. ‚Äústarter of p√¢t√©‚Äù, i.e. the first letter of ‚Äúp√¢t√©‚Äù) followed by ALL (i.e. ‚Äúthe only thing‚Äù, as in ‚Äúthat is all‚Äù) then I and ATE (i.e. ‚Äúconsumed‚Äù).

down.text: Blasted husband loves making a fuss
down.explanation: BALLYHOO(i.e. ‚Äúa fuss‚Äù). Solution is BALLY (i.e. ‚Äúblasted‚Äù, if you were Bertie Wooster, maybe) followed by H (a recognised abbreviation of ‚Äúhusband‚Äù) and OO (i.e. ‚Äúloves‚Äù, as in two zeroes ‚Äì ‚Äúlove‚Äù being a zero score in tennis).

down.text: One‚Äôs blown bonus eating goose
down.explanation: BASSOON(i.e. ‚Äúone‚Äôs blown‚Äù). Solution is BOON (i.e. ‚Äúbonus‚Äù) wrapped around or ‚Äúeating‚Äù ASS (i.e. ‚Äúgoose‚Äù, both words for a fool), like so: B(ASS)OON. Now I‚Äôm proofreading this, I can‚Äôt believe I wrote ‚Äúeating ASS‚Äù just then and didn‚Äôt snigger like‚Ä¶ well, like a massive child. Which I am doing now, obviously.

down.text: Clothing on show
down.explanation: LEGWEAR(i.e. ‚Äúclothing‚Äù). Solution is LEG (i.e. the ‚Äúon‚Äù side in cricket) followed by WEAR (i.e. ‚Äú[to] show‚Äù).

down.text: Proust novel‚Äôs dull quality
down.explanation: STUPOR(i.e. ‚Äúdull quality‚Äù). ‚ÄúNovel‚Äù indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of PROUST.

down.text: Legendary friend, one who wanders up
down.explanation: DAMON(i.e. ‚Äúlegendary friend‚Äù ‚Äì this refers to the legend of Damon and Pythias which illustrates the Pythagorean ideal of friendship. No, me neither). Solution is NOMAD (i.e. ‚Äúone who wanders‚Äù) reversed (indicated by ‚Äúup‚Äù, this being a down clue). One I got from the wordplay, clearly.

down.text: A couple of leaves, or as many as you want
down.explanation: A GOGO. Solution satisfies ‚Äúa couple of leaves‚Äù, as in A GO and GO, and ‚Äúas many as you want‚Äù.
